items.title: Sei obbligato a mantenere fratelli e sorelle senza soldi, ti tocca pagare gli alimenti: cosa dice la legge
items.description:
La solidarietà familiare in Italia non è solo un valore morale, ma un vero e proprio obbligo giuridico
L'articolo Sei obbligato a mantenere fratelli e
items.body: Sostenibilità Sei obbligato a mantenere fratelli e sorelle senza soldi, ti tocca pagare gli alimenti: cosa dice la legge    Roberto Arciola    Settembre 1, 2025     L’obbligo alimentare tra fratelli e sorelle: cosa dice la legge.  (www.greenstyle.it) La solidarietà familiare in Italia non è solo un valore morale, ma un vero e proprio obbligo giuridico sancito dalla Costituzione.Quando un familiare si trova in condizione di bisogno e non riesce a provvedere autonomamente al proprio sostentamento, la legge impone ai parenti un dovere di assistenza economica, noto come obbligo alimentare.Secondo l’articolo 2 della Costituzione e le disposizioni del Codice Civile, l’obbligo alimentare si applica per garantire le esigenze essenziali di chi versa in stato di bisogno, come vitto, alloggio e cure mediche di base. Tuttavia, questo dovere segue un ordine gerarchico preciso, stabilito dall’articolo 433 del Codice Civile: prima sono chiamati a rispondere il coniuge e i figli, quindi i genitori, poi generi, nuore, suoceri e suocere e, soltanto in ultima istanza, i fratelli e le sorelle.I fratelli sono quindi obbligati a fornire gli alimenti solo se i soggetti obbligati precedentemente risultano assenti, deceduti o in una reale impossibilità economica. Questo aspetto sottolinea il carattere sussidiario dell’obbligo alimentare, che interviene solo quando le altre figure prioritarie non possono adempiere ai propri doveri.Alimenti e mantenimento: una distinzione fondamentaleSpesso si tende a confondere il concetto di alimenti con quello di mantenimento, ma le differenze sono sostanziali. Gli alimenti coprono esclusivamente il minimo indispensabile per garantire la sopravvivenza: cibo, un luogo dove vivere e cure mediche essenziali, senza mirare a preservare lo stile di vita precedente. Il mantenimento, invece, ha un ambito più ampio e riguarda anche bisogni non strettamente essenziali, come nel caso del coniuge o dei figli dopo una separazione.Tra fratelli e sorelle si parla dunque di alimenti e non di mantenimento: ciò significa che l’aiuto economico è limitato allo stretto necessario, senza includere spese extra o lussi. In presenza di un fratello minorenne in difficoltà, la legge ammette che le spese per istruzione ed educazione possano rientrare tra le necessità primarie, ampliando così l’ammontare degli alimenti. Quando scatta l’obbligo tra fratelli e sorelle e come si quantifica (www.greenstyle.it)L’obbligo alimentare tra fratelli e sorelle non si attiva semplicemente perché uno di loro ha pochi soldi. È necessario dimostrare uno stato di bisogno reale e documentato, ovvero l’impossibilità di sostenere le spese minime di vita. Inoltre, deve risultare che i parenti obbligati prioritariamente non siano in grado di intervenire. Solo in questa circostanza i fratelli diventano i soggetti cui spetta provvedere agli alimenti.La misura dell’aiuto è proporzionata sia ai bisogni del familiare indigente sia alle capacità economiche di chi deve fornire il sostegno. Nessuno può essere obbligato a dare più di quanto possa ragionevolmente permettersi. Inoltre, l’aiuto non deve necessariamente essere in denaro: la legge consente anche l’adempimento “in natura”, come ad esempio ospitare il fratello bisognoso o sostenere direttamente le spese per alimenti e medicinali.La quantificazione degli alimenti spetta al giudice, che valuta attentamente bisogni e risorse economiche secondo gli articoli 438 e 439 del Codice Civile. Il principio è quello di garantire solo lo “stretto necessario”. Nel caso di cambiamenti nelle condizioni economiche di una delle parti, è possibile richiedere una revisione dell’importo previsto (art. 440 c.c.). Se chi riceve gli alimenti li sperpera, il giudice può anche ridurre la somma dovuta.L’obbligo alimentare tra fratelli quindi è un equilibrio delicato, basato sulla tutela del bisogno reale, sulla proporzionalità dell’aiuto e sulla possibilità di adeguamento nel tempo.La solidarietà familiare come dovere giuridicoL’impianto normativo conferma come l’aiuto tra fratelli e sorelle non sia semplicemente una questione etica, ma un dovere legale previsto per assicurare la sopravvivenza e il benessere minimo di ogni familiare. La legge tutela la persona in stato di bisogno, ma prevede anche tutele per chi deve sostenere l’onere economico, evitando richieste sproporzionate o ingiuste. Continue ReadingPrevious: Stangata per gli italiani a settembre, il caro scuola metterà a dura prova le famiglie: quanto si spenderà di più   Related Stories  Stangata per gli italiani a settembre, il caro scuola metterà a dura prova le famiglie: quanto si spenderà di più   Sostenibilità  Stangata per gli italiani a settembre, il caro scuola metterà a dura prova le famiglie: quanto si spenderà di più  Settembre 1, 2025     Un mutuo per tutti i tuoi debiti: come funziona il consolidamento e perché conviene richiederlo   Sostenibilità  Un mutuo per tutti i tuoi debiti: come funziona il consolidamento e perché conviene richiederlo  Settembre 1, 2025     Lo fai sperando di risparmiare in bolletta, ma l’effetto è opposto: l’abitudine da abbandonare subito   Sostenibilità  Lo fai sperando di risparmiare in bolletta, ma l’effetto è opposto: l’abitudine da abbandonare subito  Agosto 31, 2025

items.title: Stangata per gli italiani a settembre, il caro scuola metterà a dura prova le famiglie: quanto si spenderà di più
items.description:
Con l’avvio imminente del nuovo anno scolastico, le famiglie si trovano di fronte a un significativo aumento dei
L'articolo Stangata per gli italiani
items.body: Sostenibilità Stangata per gli italiani a settembre, il caro scuola metterà a dura prova le famiglie: quanto si spenderà di più    Roberto Arciola    Settembre 1, 2025     Aumenti significativi per libri e materiale scolastico (www.greenstyle.it) Con l’avvio imminente del nuovo anno scolastico, le famiglie si trovano di fronte a un significativo aumento dei costi legati all’istruzione.L’Unione Nazionale Consumatori (UNC) ha fornito dati aggiornati che evidenziano un aumento consistente delle spese, ben superiore all’inflazione generale, confermando una vera e propria stangata per chi deve prepararsi alla ripresa delle lezioni.Secondo le rilevazioni dell’Unione Nazionale Consumatori, il prezzo dei libri scolastici è previsto in aumento del 2,8% per il 2025, una crescita che supera il tasso d’inflazione stimato all’1,8% per i testi della scuola primaria e secondaria di primo grado. La situazione si aggrava se si considerano i dati degli ultimi anni: rispetto al 2023, l’incremento tocca il 6,7%, mentre rispetto al 2022 si arriva addirittura all’11,9%, livelli nettamente superiori all’inflazione generale certificata dall’Istat (2,9% per il 2023 e 9% rispetto al 2022).Ma l’aumento non riguarda solo i libri. Il costo del corredo scolastico si è impennato con uno zaino firmato che può superare i 200 euro, un astuccio attrezzato che arriva a 60 euro e un diario che sfiora i 40 euro. L’osservatorio di Federconsumatori stima che la spesa complessiva per studente possa superare i 1.200 euro, includendo libri, dizionari, quaderni, penne, matite e altri accessori indispensabili.Gli incrementi più preoccupanti riguardano articoli di cancelleria come penne, matite ed evidenziatori, con rincari del 6,9% rispetto al 2024, del 16,6% rispetto al 2022 e addirittura del 24,2% rispetto al 2021. Anche quadernoni e risme di carta hanno subito aumenti medi dell’1,5% rispetto all’anno precedente, ma considerando i maxi rincari del 2022 (+9,8%) e del 2023 (+7,5%), il costo complessivo di questi prodotti è salito del 20,3% in quattro anni.Il peso degli aumenti sugli studenti universitari e il ruolo dell’editoriaL’Unione Nazionale Consumatori segnala inoltre come la situazione sia pesante anche per gli studenti universitari: gli alloggi per studenti hanno registrato un aumento medio del 6% rispetto al 2024 e del 13,6% rispetto al 2023. Questo contribuisce ad aggravare ulteriormente il bilancio delle famiglie.L’attenzione è però focalizzata soprattutto sui prezzi dei libri scolastici, oggetto in passato di critiche da parte dell’Autorità Garante della Concorrenza e del Mercato (AGCM). Nei mesi scorsi, l’Autorità ha denunciato un quadro di prezzi in crescita, scarsa concorrenza nel settore editoriale, ostacoli al mercato dell’usato e limiti eccessivi agli sconti praticabili. Attualmente, infatti, è vietato alle grandi catene di supermercati e alle piattaforme digitali applicare sconti superiori al 15% sul prezzo di copertina, mentre nel 2019 si arrivava anche al 25%.La spesa media per studente si attesta intorno ai 580 euro nelle scuole medie e supera i 1.250 euro nelle superiori, un dato che non beneficia ancora in modo significativo dell’introduzione del digitale. Il 95% delle classi utilizza infatti ancora la versione cartacea dei testi, spesso affiancata da un ebook concesso solo in licenza e non rivendibile, limitando così i margini di risparmio per le famiglie. Strategie e consigli per contenere la spesa scolastica(www.greenstyle.it)Per contrastare il caro scuola, le associazioni di consumatori come Federconsumatori e Assoutenti hanno elaborato una serie di consigli pratici per aiutare le famiglie a contenere i costi:Favorire l’acquisto di libri usati: selezionando con attenzione l’edizione necessaria, si può risparmiare dal 26% fino al 50% rispetto al nuovo, con un impatto positivo anche in termini di sostenibilità ambientale. Esistono numerose piattaforme online, gruppi social e mercatini dedicati allo scambio e alla vendita di testi usati.Utilizzare dispense e materiali forniti dagli insegnanti: molti docenti mettono a disposizione dispense e materiali didattici per limitare la necessità di acquistare tutti i libri di testo.Acquistare presso la grande distribuzione organizzata (GDO): supermercati e ipermercati offrono spesso prezzi più competitivi rispetto alle cartolerie specializzate, con un risparmio medio stimato intorno al 19% sul corredo scolastico.Sfruttare le versioni digitali: quando disponibili, gli ebook possono costare fino al 39% in meno rispetto alla versione cartacea. Anche l’acquisto online può generare risparmi tra il 10 e il 12%.Verificare sconti e coupon: molti punti vendita propongono promozioni e sconti sul prezzo di copertina dei libri, che possono arrivare fino al 20%.Il presidente di Federconsumatori, Furio Truzzi, invita inoltre il governo a collaborare con produttori e grandi distributori per ideare kit scolastici a prezzi calmierati, limitando così gli aumenti ingiustificati e aiutando concretamente le famiglie in difficoltà. Continue ReadingPrevious: Un mutuo per tutti i tuoi debiti: come funziona il consolidamento e perché conviene richiederloNext: Sei obbligato a mantenere fratelli e sorelle senza soldi, ti tocca pagare gli alimenti: cosa dice la legge   Related Stories  Sei obbligato a mantenere fratelli e sorelle senza soldi, ti tocca pagare gli alimenti: cosa dice la legge   Sostenibilità  Sei obbligato a mantenere fratelli e sorelle senza soldi, ti tocca pagare gli alimenti: cosa dice la legge  Settembre 1, 2025     Un mutuo per tutti i tuoi debiti: come funziona il consolidamento e perché conviene richiederlo   Sostenibilità  Un mutuo per tutti i tuoi debiti: come funziona il consolidamento e perché conviene richiederlo  Settembre 1, 2025     Lo fai sperando di risparmiare in bolletta, ma l’effetto è opposto: l’abitudine da abbandonare subito   Sostenibilità  Lo fai sperando di risparmiare in bolletta, ma l’effetto è opposto: l’abitudine da abbandonare subito  Agosto 31, 2025

items.title: Geotermia: il calore sotto i nostri piedi, l’energia che non usiamo
items.description: Come funziona la geotermia e perché soddisfa solo lo 0,3 per cento dell’elettricità mondiale. Storia di una fonte energetica trascurata.
items.body:
Cina, le rinnovabili per la prima volta superano il carbone

Energie rinnovabili. Cosa sono, il potenziale globale, gli impianti migliori
		
		
			Le enormi riserve di combustibili naturali formatisi nel corso dell’evoluzione del nostro pianeta, sedimentate nelle profondità della crosta terrestre e lì conservate per milioni di anni, le stiamo bruciando tutte in un secolo. Petrolio, carbone e gas metano coprono oggi l’80% del fabbisogno energetico mondiale; un altro 6% circa è coperto da materiale fissile (essenzialmente
		
		
			 Energia
			5 dicembre 2023
			
				di Stefano Carnazzi

Come il Kenya è diventato leader nelle rinnovabili in Africa
		
		
			Trecentodieci megawatt di energia rinnovabile, accessibile, economica. È quanto le 365 turbine eoliche del Turkana Wind Power sono in grado di produrre da quando, lo scorso settembre, sono entrate in funzione e allacciate alla rete elettrica kenyota. Negli ultimi otto mesi, il parco eolico ha permesso di ridurre la spesa di quasi 70 milioni di
		
		
			 Energia
			6 settembre 2019
			
				di Rudi Bressa

2020: le energie rinnovabili sono più competitive dei combustibili fossili
		
		
			Secondo l’Irena il 2020 sarà l’anno in cui le tutte le energie rinnovabili diventeranno più convenienti di carbone, petrolio e gas naturale.
		
		
			 Energia
			27 gennaio 2018
			
				di Cecilia Bergamasco

Un angolo di Toscana da tutelare, in un video: Casole d’Elsa e Radicondoli
			
			
				Casole d’Elsa e Radicondoli, il video su questo angolo di Toscana da tutelare mostra la bellezza del territorio e spiega perché è importante progetterlo.

Ambiente

5 giugno 2017

Masso delle Fanciulle. Un luogo del cuore che merita di essere tutelato
			
			
				Il Masso delle Fanciulle è un luogo incantato, entrato nel cuore di chi l’ha vissuto o incontrato sul suo cammino. Ecco perché merita di essere tutelato. Con il tuo voto.

Biodiversità

21 giugno 2016

Il fascino discreto della vulcanologia
			
			
				Trattasi di montagne, sì, ma di fuoco, poiché si situano all’interno delle cosiddette aree geodinamiche della superficie terrestre, ovvero nei luoghi geologicamente più attivi del pianeta in cui possono più frequentemente verificarsi sia le eruzioni sia i terremoti. Ed è proprio quest’indole “irrequieta” ed effervescente a conferire ai vulcani quel fascino spettacolare e lievemente sinistro

Mostre

26 aprile 2016

Geotermia, a Roma un dibattito senza la voce dei cittadini
			
			
				Il 31 marzo si tiene a Roma un convegno sulla geotermia dal titolo Speciale geotermia. Il futuro a emissioni zero è già qui. L’intento dovrebbe essere quello di mettere a confronto attivisti per l’ambiente, imprenditori e politici su un argomento che riguarda il futuro di tutti: come fornire energia al nostro paese in modo sostenibile.

Centrali elettriche

27 marzo 2015

La Costa Rica si è alimentata con energia rinnovabile per 75 giorni consecutivi
			
			
				Grazie soprattutto alle forti piogge e all’energia geotermica il Paese centroamericano ha impiegato per oltre due mesi solo energia pulita.

Ambiente

23 marzo 2015

Geotermia, la risposta del Comitato Difensori della Toscana a Jacopo Fo
			
			
				Sul sito www.tekneco.it è stata recentemente pubblicata un’intervista di Gianluigi Torchiani a Jacopo Fo. L’intervista si intitola “La moratoria sulla geotermia toscana è un colpo di coda della vecchia energia”. L’articolo merita un’analisi accurata, perché rappresenta un esempio di un modo di argomentare che arricchisce la casistica del Sole24Ore sul pensiero antiscientifico. In una discussione scientifica sarebbe utile

Energia

20 febbraio 2015

items.title: Projections of climate change vulnerability along the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways 2020–2100
items.body:
Download PDF

Data Descriptor
    
        
            Open access

Published: 01 September 2025

Projections of climate change vulnerability along the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways 2020–2100
                    Janine Huisman1, Rosanne Martyr2,3, René Rott2 & …Jeroen Smits1 Show authors

Scientific Data

volume 12, Article number: 1527 (2025)
            Cite this article

Subjects
        
            Climate-change mitigationProjection and predictionSocioeconomic scenarios

AbstractThis data descriptor presents the GVI Projections Database with projections of socioeconomic vulnerability for the period 2020–2100 along three Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) for almost all countries of the world. The projections are based on the GDL Vulnerability Index (GVI), a composite index for monitoring the human components of vulnerability to climate change, natural disasters and other shocks for societies and geographic areas across the globe. The GVI is based on an additive formula that summarizes the essence of seven major socioeconomic dimensions of vulnerability into one number. This formula approach makes it possible to compute the index for any region at any point in time for which the underlying indicators are available. We derive projections of these indicators from the SSP databases for each fifth year in the period 2020–2100. These projections are subsequently used to compute future GVI values for countries and major global regions for three SSPs: the green road scenario (SSP1), the middle of the road scenario (SSP2), and the rocky road scenario (SSP3).

Background & SummaryIn this data descriptor we present the GVI Projections Database with projections of the GDL Vulnerability Index (GVI) along three Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) for the period 2020–2100 for 180 countries. The GVI is a composite index for monitoring the human components of vulnerability to climate change, disasters and other kinds of shocks1. It captures structural and institutional characteristics of societies that shape how populations are affected by external stressors and how they are able to respond.As awareness has grown that hazard-focused approaches are insufficient to address climate change and related disasters, attention has increasingly turned to reducing the social and institutional conditions that render populations at risk2,3. Risk is defined as the potential for adverse consequences for human or ecological systems, and in the context of climate change can arise from potential impacts of climate change as well as human responses to climate change4. Growing knowledge of the interactions of multiple drivers of risk, along with the links between physical and social drivers, has led to the development of frameworks for climate change risk assessments5,6.The IPCC’s Sixth Assessment Report7,8,9 frames climate risk as the interaction of three pillars: climate hazards, exposure, and vulnerability. The pillar of climate hazards is often addressed through estimates and projections of Climate Impact Drivers (CIDs), defined as the physical climate conditions including means, extremes and events, that affect an element of society or ecosystem10. Exposure refers to the presence of people, ecosystems, assets (be they social, economic or cultural), infrastructure and livelihoods that could be adversely impacted by climate hazards and CIDs4. Vulnerability, in this context, reflects both sensitivity—the degree to which systems are affected by climate-related hazards—and adaptive capacity—the ability to cope with, adjust to, or transform in response to those hazards. Increased attention has been brought to the multiple and intersecting drivers of vulnerability and the interactions between these drivers, which can lead to differential outcomes of climate risk11,12,13.The GVI is a composite vulnerability index that contributes to, and aligns with, the IPCC risk framework by providing estimates and projections of socioeconomic vulnerability along climate and socioeconomic scenarios that can be readily integrated with hazards and exposure to provide estimates and projections of climate risk. The GVI operationalizes the vulnerability pillar of the IPCC risk framework by drawing on eleven internationally comparable indicators that show the variation in vulnerability across seven socioeconomic dimensions: the economy, education, health, gender, infrastructure, governance, and demographics. It can be integrated with both extreme events—such as droughts, floods, and heatwaves—and gradual climate shifts, including long-term changes in temperature and precipitation. As such, it provides a people-centred tool for identifying regions most at risk through social drivers of risk, and for informing adaptive-capacity strategies that prioritize human well-being and societal resilience.The GVI is more flexible than other established vulnerability indices like the NDGAIN of the University of Notre Dame14 (ND-GAIN), the INFORM Risk Index of the Joint Research Centre of the European Commission15 (INFORM), or the WorldRiskIndex16 (WRI), which are constructed by teams of experts and released annually. These indices are ingenious and encompassing and include large numbers of underlying indicators (27–54). However, they are not very flexible. The user has to take them as-they-are and for the aggregation level for which they are published (i.e. the country level) and no future projections are yet available.The GVI is different in that it focuses only on the core dimensions of socioeconomic vulnerability and uses a data-driven approach that is less dependent on expert judgement. It is based on a simple additive formula, with which any region in the world for which the underlying indicators are available can be ranked on the GVI scale1. Given that always the same formula is used, GVI scores are comparable between areas (countries, groupings of countries or subnational areas) and over time.Despite its simplicity, the GVI ranks countries similar to the more sophisticated vulnerability indices mentioned above. Validation analyses revealed very high Pearson correlations (.77-.94) with the coping capacity, adaptive capacity and susceptibility subdimensions of ND-GAIN, INFORM and WRI1. This gives confidence that also in settings for which no other indices exist (e.g. subnational regions, groupings of countries) the GVI may provide a good indication of these aspects of the region’s vulnerability.The GVI is currently available at the level of countries and larger global geographic areas for the period 2000–20201. However, given its formula-based approach, GVI values can potentially be computed for any region and any point in time for which the underlying indicators are available. Here we use this possibility to create projections of socioeconomic vulnerability according to three scenarios developed as part of the Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs).The SSPs are narratives describing plausible socioeconomic futures that can be associated with different challenges regarding climate change impact, mitigation and adaptation17,18,19. In the GVI Projections Database we present projections of GVI along SSP1, a pathway with very low greenhouse gas emissions (‘green road’), SSP2, a pathway corresponding to current climate pledges and development (‘middle of the road’), and SSP3, a pathway with fragmentation and conflict at the national and international level with high challenges to mitigation and adaptation (‘rocky road’).While projections alongside these pathways have been developed for economic, demographic, educational, gender and other indicators that represent the human aspects of vulnerability, no projections are yet available for a composite index that brings together the values of these indicators into one authoritative number. In the GVI Projections Database, we make such projections available for the period 2020–2100 on the basis of the GVI.Dimensions of vulnerabilityThe GVI concentrates on the human and societal dimensions of vulnerability as experienced by communities or geographic regions1. It brings together seven key thematic domains, each represented by specific indicators, as outlined in Table 1.Table 1 Dimensions and indicators on which the GVI is baseda.Full size tableThe economic dimension refers to the ability of economic actors, such as households, companies or states, to prepare for and cope with climate change events, as well as the damage and economic loss caused by such events2. Less developed areas and poorer households are more vulnerable to the impacts of natural hazards and are more at risk of suffering negative effects of climate change20,21,22. The economic dimension is represented in the GVI by Gross Domestic Product per capita (GDPc) and the Poverty Headcount at USD 3.65.People and societies with a higher level of education are more aware of the possible risks of climate change, are better prepared for disasters and respond more adequate to them. Consequently they tend to suffer less negative impact and recover faster21,23. Education is measured by the mean years of schooling of the adult (25+) population.Vulnerability to climate change is gender related21,24. Women and girls are at greater risk of dying in disasters, they are often not included in decision making and are sometimes acted against in recovery and reconstruction projects25,26. Gender makes people not necessarily vulnerable through biology, but as a consequence of societal structures and roles2,22. Gender inequality is measured with the Gender Development Index (GDI)27. The GDI is an index developed by the United Nations Development Program (UNDP) to measure gender-based disparities in three key dimensions of human development: health, education, and standard of living28,29. The GDI essentially compares the level of development for women and men to assess the extent of gender inequality in a country.A weak health status of the population –e.g. a higher prevalence of chronic diseases or obesity –or inadequate health systems –lack of medicines, doctors, hospitals and laboratories –may increase vulnerability to climate change considerably30,31,32,33. Life expectation at birth is generally considered an indicator of quantity and quality of life34 and was selected by Smits and Huisman1 to measure population health. Higher life expectancy is supposed to indicate better living conditions such as improved sanitation and nutrition, healthcare, and public health.Inadequate infrastructure is an important driver of vulnerability to climate change. People without access to clean drinking water are more vulnerable to disease in the aftermath of a hazard35. Electricity is essential for preparing and acting in times of emergencies. Communication means such as mobile phones may help reduce the impact of climate change through early warning signals and help to smooth the organization of post-event responses36,37.Good quality governance makes it easier to develop strategies and implement policies to deal with the impacts of climate change and to act in times of crisis38. Governance is measured by the Worldwide Governance Indicators of the World Bank (WGI), which describe patterns in the perception of the quality of governance. The WGI are based on data collected by over 30 sources (international organizations, nongovernmental organizations, private firms, etc.) and reflect the views of survey respondents and experts regarding six dimensions of governance: Voice and Accountability, Political Stability and Absence of Violence/Terrorism, Government Effectiveness, Regulatory Quality, Rule of Law, Control of Corruption39.Demographic factors like age structure and population density are important too22,40. The very young and old are more vulnerable than others due to ‘biological sensitivity’21,35,40,41,42. Age structure will be indicated by the dependency ratio, which compares the number of young and old individuals (i.e. the non-working or dependent population) with the number of individuals in the working age population43. Rural communities are more vulnerable, as they may have lower priority for governments or are isolated22,44. Urban areas generally have better facilities and their population is easier to reach in case of disasters, lowering vulnerability1. Urbanization as our second demographic factor is measured by the percentage of the population living in urban area.Smits and Huisman1 did not incorporate physical characteristics such as landscape, soil types, natural vegetation, or human-environment interactions, like agriculture or nature management, as they wanted to create an index that is completely human oriented. This makes sense, as the human components of vulnerability tend to be highly correlated)45,46 and thus make up a strong index, which has the additional advantage that it can be used as an independent indicator to study the variation in the environment-related aspects.Pathways into the futureThe Shared Socioeconomic Pathways (SSPs) is a set of scenarios used in the IPCC Sixth Assessment47 that explore possible future outcomes regarding central human components known to influence and be influenced by climate change17,18. These pathways provide an operational scenario framework of possible futures and the extent to which these create challenges to climate change mitigation and adaptation. Each SSP explores a possible future that illustrates how socioeconomic development might change in the course of the current century, based on assumptions about population and economic growth, technological progress, and societal values.SSP1, the ‘green road’ pathway, is characterized by a shift to sustainable development and improvement of environmental conditions, with more renewable energy supply, less land use and lower anthropogenic greenhouse gas emissions in 210048. Under this pathway, investments in education and health increase, inequality within and between countries declines, and the focus on economic growth shifts toward an emphasis on human well-being.Pathway SSP2 is broadly a continuation of historical patterns in social, economic, and technological development, and is considered a ‘middle of the road’ path regarding challenges to mitigation and adaptation49. Under this pathway, economic growth and development is uneven and static, and progress towards achieving the United Nations Sustainable Development Goals (SDGs) is slow.SSP3, the ‘rocky road’ pathway, is characterized by high challenges to mitigation and adaptation50. Countries’ main focus are national interests, particularly regarding energy and food goals, with reduced support for international institutions and cooperation and low international priority for addressing environmental concerns. These characteristics lead to a decline in education and technological investments, and strong environmental degradation in some regions. Population growth is low in industrialized nations and high in developing countries, and inequalities persist or worsen over time.Besides these three major pathways – which provide a clear distinction between three recognizable storylines – there are two additional pathways, SSP4 and SSP5. Of these pathways, SSP4 focuses on inequalities within and across countries and regions and is characterized by low challenges to mitigation and high challenges to adaptation51, while SSP5 represents a ‘fossil-fueled development’ pathway in which fossil fuel development is intensified at the price of substantial environmental degradation52. Here we focus on the first three SSPs due to similarities between SSP3 and SSP4 in terms of adaptive capacity and low plausibility of SSP5 due to the scale of increased fossil fuel development in the pathway which is not in line with global trajectories of fossil fuel development and emissions52,53.The SSP pathways have been quantified in future projections of population54, GDP55,56, income inequality and poverty57, urbanization58, education54, the Human Development Index59, governance38 and gender inequality60. This broad set of indicators overlaps considerably with the indicators used to create the GVI. This offers the opportunity to project the GVI into the future along the SSPs and use it to investigate vulnerability trends. Such projections have the great advantage that for each SSP only one vulnerability value per time point is obtained, which makes it simpler to compare countries and regions and obtain a clearer picture of where and under which circumstances vulnerability issues can be expected.MethodsThe GVI was constructed by Smits and Huisman1 on the basis of eleven indicators derived from the World Bank and the UNDP. GDP per capita and the poverty headcount ratio at US$ 3.65 a day (both in constant 2017 International Dollars PPP), the percentages of people using safely managed drinking water services, with access to electricity and living in urban areas, the number of mobile cellular subscriptions per 100 people, and the Dependency Ratio (dependent population (below 15 and over 65) divided by working age population) were derived from the World Development Indicators Database (WDI, https://databank.worldbank.org/source/world-development-indicators) of the World Bank. Mean years of schooling of the adult (25+) population, life expectancy at birth and the Gender Development Index (GDI) were derived from the Human Development Index Database (HDID, https://hdr.undp.org/data-center) of the UNDP61 and governance as indicated by the Worldwide Governance Indicators (WGI)39 was derived from the WGI Database of the World Bank (https://www.worldbank.org/en/publication/worldwide-governance-indicators).To construct the GVI, Smits and Huisman1 applied Principal Component Analysis (PCA) to this set of indicators for the years 2015–2020 to determine the indicator weights62,63,64. The first component, explaining two-third of the variation in the indicator set, was chosen as the raw vulnerability index, which was subsequently translated into an indicator running from 0 to 100–with the value of 100 indicating highest vulnerability – to create the GVI1. The indicator weights in the PCA analysis showed that all indicators contributed substantially to the index, with somewhat higher contributions for poverty and life expectancy and somewhat lower contributions for the GDI and urbanization. Details of this analysis can be found in Smits and Huisman1.The GVI Projections Database presents projections of the GVI alongside three SSPs for each fifth year of the period 2020–2100. GVI values for 2020 derived from Smits and Huisman1 are used as starting point. Their database contains the actual World Bank and UNDP country scores on the underlying eleven indicators for this year. The projections for 2025–2100 are based on data from several SSP databases. For population by age group (used to calculate the dependency ratio), GDP per capita, poverty, urbanization, and education, data are derived from version 3.1.0 of the SSP database of IIASA (https://data.ece.iiasa.ac.at/ssp)17,19,55,56,65. Life expectancy at birth projections are obtained from the Data Explorer of the Wittgenstein Centre for Demography and Global Human Capital (http://dataexplorer.wittgensteincentre.org/wcde-v2/)59. Governance data were derived from Andrijevic et al.38.Given that the values of the data derived from these sources are not always exactly equal to the World Bank/UNDP data used to construct the original GVI formula, several adjustments had to be made. For GDP per capita, life expectancy, urbanization and the dependency ratio, the definitions used in the SSP databases are basically the same as those of the World Bank or UNDP, but nevertheless some minor to moderate differences turned out to exist for 2020-data. To address these differences, a two-step adjustment procedure was used, based on three assumptions: 1) the World Bank and UNDP values for 2020 are the true values for that year, 2) the values in the projections database are the best estimates for the later part of the century, and 3) the five-year trends in the projections database are the true trends.In the first step of the adjustment procedure, we have taken for each indicator (I) the World Bank/UNDP values for 2020 and applied for each subsequent five-year period the proportional change of the corresponding indicator in the projections database (P). This was done using the following formula:$${I}_{y}={I}_{y-5}\,\ast \,{P}_{y}/{P}_{y-5}$$
                    (1)
                Whereby Iy represents the estimated value of the indicator in year y, Iy-5 the value of that indicator five years earlier, Py the value of the corresponding indicator in the projections database and Py-5 the value of that indicator five years earlier. By applying this formula to each five-year period between 2020 and 2100, starting with the ‘true’ World Bank and UNDP values for 2020, indicator estimates for each fifth year in this period were obtained.While for 2020 these estimates are based on the best available data, i.e. the World Bank and UNDP data for that year, we assume that for the later part of the century projections in the SSP databases are the best available values. In the second step of the procedure, we therefore apply an algorithm that for each subsequent five-year period between 2020 and 2100 gives less weight to the World Bank/UNDP based values for Iy created in the first step and more weight to the values from the projection databases Py. This is done using the following formula:$${F}_{y}={Step}\,\ast \,{P}_{y}+\left(16-{Step}\right)\,\ast \,{I}_{y}$$
                    (2)
                Whereby Fy is the final value of the indicator that will be used to compute the GVI projections and Step is an integer with value 0 in 2020, 1 in 2025, 2 in 2030, …. 14 in 2090, 15 in 2095 and 16 in 2100. In this way, projection data were created for GDPc, life expectancy, the dependency ratio and urbanization.For the other indicators additional steps were required, because the definitions did not coincide, or no projection data was available. Differences in definition existed for education, poverty and governance. For constructing versions of these indicators in line with the GVI definitions, the following steps were made.For education, the variable in the GVI Database is mean years of education completed by the adult (25+) population, while the IIASA database provides education levels based on the International Standard Classification of Education66. These levels are: (E1) ‘no education’, including no formal education or less than one year primary; (E2) ‘primary’, including incomplete primary, completed primary, and incomplete lower secondary; (E3) ‘secondary’, including completed lower secondary (ISCED 2), incomplete and completed higher secondary (ISCED 3/4), and incomplete tertiary education; (E4) ‘tertiary’, including completed tertiary education (ISCED 5/6)67,68. To translate these levels into years of education, we compute what Kc et al.67 call the “Mean Years of Schooling Equivalent” (MYSE)67, whereby E1 is assigned 0 years, E2 5.2 years, E3 11.4 years, and E4 15.5 years. Given that the most recent version of the IIASA database contains also the categories ‘incomplete primary’ and ‘lower secondary’ we have refined the procedure by giving ‘incomplete primary’ the value 2.6 (E2/2) and ‘lower secondary’ the value 8.3 ((E2 + E3)/2).For poverty, an extra translation step had to be made, as the poverty measure included in the SSP projections database was the poverty headcount ratio at US$ 3.20 a day in 2011 international dollars PPP. However, in 2022 the World Bank has adjusted the international poverty lines based on 2011 prices to equivalent values based on 2017 prices. This led to an increase of the US$ 3.20 poverty line to US$ 3.6569. The poverty headcount ratio in the GVI Database is based on this new definition. Although Jolliffe et al.69 show that both definitions are equivalent for the world as a whole, for individual countries there may be some differences. To take such potential differences into account, we have developed a regression based linear prediction model that translates the 2020 values from the SSP projections database into the definition used in the GVI Database. This prediction model has a high explained variance (adj. R2) of 91.4%, hence the prediction is expected to be very good. The model is:$${Pov}365=1.11173802\ast {Pov}320$$
                    (3)
                Whereby Pov365 represents the poverty headcount ratio at US$ 3.65 a day in 2017 international dollars PPP and Pov320 the poverty headcount ratio at US$ 3.20 a day in 2011 international dollars PPP. Given the equivalence of both definitions and the fact that in many countries the percentages of the population under this poverty line is zero, or will reach zero in the course of the century, a regression model without intercept is used to guarantee that for countries in which Pov320 is zero also Pov365 will be zero. To gain additional information about the quality of the model, in the Technical Validation section a graph showing the predicted values of the model against the outcome variable is presented in Fig. 5.For governance, we had to translate the projections of the WGI developed by Andrijevic et al.38 into the version used in the GVI Database. To do this, we developed a regression based linear prediction model with which the WGI of the GVI Database for 2020 was predicted on the basis of the WGI of Andrijevic et al.38 The prediction model has a high explained variance (adj. R2) of 94.6% and the graph of the predicted values against the outcome variable in the Technical Validation section (Fig. 5) reveals a strong relationship. The model is:$${WGI}={-}2.72544960+4.70366071\ast {WGIA}.$$
                    (4)
                The SSP projection databases contain no data for the GDI, the number of mobile cellular subscriptions per 100 people, the percentage of people with access to electricity and the percentage of people using safely managed drinking water services. To obtain estimates of these indicators alongside the SSPs, the following procedures were used.Regarding gender, there are projections of the Gender Inequality Index (GII) available60. However, in the GVI Database the UNDP’s GDI27 is used to indicate gender inequality and for the GDI no projections are available. To create such projections, we followed an approach similar to Andrijevic et al.60 and developed a linear regression model in which the 2020 GDI values in the GVI Database are predicted on the basis of other gender sensitive indices for that year, derived from the SSP projection databases. For this purpose, four indicators were used: (1) the difference in years of education completed between males and females (EDIF), (2) mean years of education in the country (EDU), (3) the difference in life expectancy at birth between males and females (LEDIF) and (4) number of children under 10 of women aged 15–49 (NCHILD). The model has an explained variance (adj. R2) of 66.4% which can be considered as a good fit for this kind of data70. The model is:$${GDI}=0.91057399-0.01670565\ast {EDIF}+0.02158426\ast {EDU}+0.00775785\ast {LEDIF}-0.03096256\ast {NCHILD}$$
                    (5)
                For access to electricity and mobile cellular subscriptions per 100 people, no projection data are available. It is complicated to create such projections based on past experiences, as the spread of these provisions is a one-time process. Moreover, the low-income, mostly African, countries that currently still lag behind are difficult to compare with other countries as they are exceptional in many regards and suffer from stagnation in economic, educational, demographic and infrastructural development43,71,72,73.Given the experiences in other parts of the world, it seems likely that somewhere in the coming decades global saturation in electricity and phone connections will be reached. However, the main question is when this will be the case. Given the focus on equality and human wellbeing in SSP1, we expect saturation to be reached first under this scenario, whereas the conflicts and increasing inequalities under SSP3 may lead to the longest delay. In our analyses we therefore assume that under SSP1 global saturation in electricity connections and mobile cellular subscriptions will be reached in 2040, hence 15 years from now. For SSP2 we assume that saturation will be reached ten years later, in 2050 and for SSP3 again ten years later, in 2060.As these assumptions may be overly optimistic or pessimistic, we have also tested two alternative scenarios. A more optimistic one that assumes saturation to be reached already in 2030, 2040 and 2050, and a more pessimistic one assuming that saturation will be reached in 2050, 2060 and 2070. In the Technical Validation Section these alternative scenarios are used in a robustness test to find out to what extent our GVI predictions are sensitive to these choices.For the remaining indicator, safely managed drinking water services, it is more difficult to make predictions. The availability of water is more directly connected to climate change than the availability of electricity or phone connections, which depend much more on technological developments. We therefore have decided to leave this indicator out of our projection models and to create the GVI projections using ten indicators. Smits and Huisman1 present separate GVI formulas for the situation that one of the indicators is missing and show that GVI scores based on ten instead of eleven indicators are very highly correlated with the original GVI scores (Pearson correlations >0.99). Such stability against removal of one or more underlying indices has been found also for other composite indices like the International Wealth Index64 and the Subnational Corruption Index74. We therefore expect that leaving out the water indicators will have little influence on the GVI projections.Following the procedures discussed above, we have created a GVI Projections Database with indicator values for the three scenarios for every fifth year in the period 2020–2100 for 180 countries.Constructing the indexIn the final step of the procedure, the GVI values for the period 2020–2100 are computed on the basis of the ten indicators in the GVI Projections Database, using the appropriate formula derived from Smits and Huisman1. The indicator weights of this formula are presented in Table 2 under ‘All’. To compute the GVI on the basis of these weights, the indicator values were multiplied with their weight and summed up. This procedure is shown in the following equation, where GVI’ is the estimated vulnerability score, βn the indicator weight of the nth indicator and xn the indicator value of the nth indicator.$${{\rm{G}}{\rm{V}}{\rm{I}}}^{{\rm{{\prime} }}}=-18.47701316+\sum {\beta }_{n}\cdot {x}_{n}$$
                    (6)
                Table 2 Indicator weights for computing GVI on the basis of all indicators or with one or two indicators missing.Full size tableOn the GVI′ scale constructed in this way higher values refer to countries that are less vulnerable, which is not very intuitive. We therefore have reversed the scale to create the final GVI scale in the following way:$${GVI}=100-{GVI}{\prime} $$
                    (7)
                The GVI constructed in this way runs potentially from zero to 100, with zero meaning very low vulnerability and 100 extreme vulnerability. After this transformation, the GVI values were added to the database. Given that the GVI version computed here does not include the water variable, the values for 2020 might deviate slightly from those presented by Smits and Huisman1.Using this approach, GVI values could be computed for 162 of the 180 countries in the database. For 15 countries one indicator was missing in the database. For Syria and Venezuela GDPc was missing, whereas for Guyana and Ireland the 2020 values of GDPc differed so much between the SSP and World Bank databases that we decided not to use them. Albania, Angola, Emirates, Monte Negro, Myanmar, Timor-Leste and Qatar were missing WGI, and Eritrea, Grenada, Liberia and South Sudan were missing poverty. Of the three remaining countries, Afghanistan and Palestine were missing data on GDP per capita and governance and Hong Kong was missing data on urbanization and life expectancy. To obtain estimates of the GVI projections of the countries with one or two indicators missing, alternative formulas have been developed. The indicator weights of these formulas are presented in Table 2.Fig. 1 presents maps with the GVI starting values in 2020 (top map) and the projected values according to the three SSP scenarios for 2050 and 2100 at world scale. The maps in the second row are for SSP1, those in the third row for SSP2 and those at the bottom for SSP3. Comparison of the 2050 map (left) with the 2100 map (right) for the green road scenario (SSP1) reveals a large decrease in vulnerability over that period. The maps for the middle of the road scenario (SSP2) in the third row, show slower, but still substantial decreases under that scenario, while in those for the rocky road scenario (SSP3) at the bottom of the figure, very little improvement is observed.Fig. 1Maps of GVI for 2020 and under SSPs 1, 2 and 3 for 2050 and 2100. Colors indicate country-level (national) values. Higher values (red, orange) indicate higher levels of vulnerability.Full size imageThese observations are confirmed in Fig. 2, which shows clear decreases of median GVI values under SSP1 but little change under SSP3. The spread in socioeconomic conditions is smallest under SSP1, wider under SSP2, and widest under SSP3, where large gaps in GVI persist between countries throughout the century.Fig. 2Projected values of GVI (national values in grey; country median in blue; Q1 to Q3 quantile range shown in blue shading) for period 2020–2100 for three climate-development pathways: (a) SSP1 - the ‘green road’ scenario; (b) SSP2 - the ‘middle of the road’ scenario; and c) SSP3 - the ‘rocky road’ scenario’.Full size imageThe GVI projections also display regional patterns in socioeconomic vulnerability. In Fig. 3, this is shown for 20 UN Geoscheme regions (the M49 standard75, with Micronesia, Melanesia and Polynesia combined into one region). Northern America, Northern and Western Europe and Australia and New Zealand show the lowest regional GVI values in 2050 and 2100, while regions in Africa, Southern Asia and the Pacific Island States have the highest projected values. These patterns are maintained across the pathways and reflect regional disparities that are already exhibited in present-day GVI scores.Fig. 3Projected GVI (region median in colour bars, range shown in error bars) for three climate-development pathways (in rows) at three discrete times: 2030 (left column), 2050 (middle column) and 2100 (right column). The climate-development pathways are: (a–c) SSP1 – the ‘green road’ pathway; (d–f) SSP2 – the ‘middle of the road’ pathway; and g-i) SSP3 – the ‘rocky road’ pathway.Full size imageUnder the sustainable development pathway (SSP1), regions with relatively high vulnerability at present-day levels exhibit the largest decrease in GVI values and potential improvement in socioeconomic conditions (Fig. 3a–c). In contrast, disparities in GVI are largest under the SSP3 pathway within and across regions, and persist throughout the century (Fig. 3g–i). This pattern reflects the scenario’s storyline of regional fragmentation.Differences between low, middle, and high vulnerability countriesBased on present-day values of GVI, countries are binned into equal categories of low, middle and high vulnerability (Fig. 4). In 2020, these groups were very different. The low vulnerable countries exhibited a median value of 25, the middle vulnerable countries of approximately 40, and the highly vulnerable countries of almost 70. The projections over the 21st century reveal the most substantial decrease in socioeconomic vulnerability in highly vulnerable countries. Low vulnerability countries exhibit the smallest decrease in GVI over time, due to already low vulnerability at present-day.Fig. 4Projected GVI (median) over the period 2020–2100 for three vulnerability levels: low (shown in green), middle (shown in orange), and high (shown in red). The shaded areas indicate the Q1 to Q3 range for each vulnerability level. Projections are provided for three climate-development pathways: (a) SSP1 – the ‘green road’ pathway; (b) SSP2 – the ‘middle of the road’ pathway; and (c) SSP3 – the ‘rocky road’ pathway.Full size imageAll groups exhibit the largest decrease in GVI and highest potential for improvement of their socioeconomic conditions under the SSP1 pathway. Highly vulnerable countries in particular could experience socioeconomic conditions on par with low-vulnerable countries under this pathway. The SSP3 pathway results in the lowest decreases in socioeconomic vulnerability, with highly vulnerable countries still experiencing higher vulnerability in the future than experienced by low or middle-vulnerable countries presently.Data RecordsThe GVI Projections Database consists of a zip-archive that contains the dataset with projected values of the GVI and the ten underlying indicators for three SSPs and for each five-year period between 2020 and 2100 for 180 countries from all regions of the world. The dataset is available in four different versions: SPSS, STATA, MS Excel and as CSV.The archive also contains an SPSS-syntax file “GVI Projections Scientific Data.sps”, which presents the code for computing the projected GVI values from the indicators. A Readme-file with information is also included.The GVI Projections Database is publicly available as a zip-file from the Figshare repository76. The database can also be downloaded from the website of the Global Data Lab (www.globaldatalab.org), where future updates will be made available and visualizations can be made.Preliminary projections for SSP1 and SSP3 were made available in the Biophysical Data Explorer of Climate Vulnerability Monitor 3 of the Climate Vulnerability Forum (https://www.v-20.org/climatevulnerabilitymonitor).Technical ValidationStability of the indexTo test the stability of the index, several robustness tests were performed. Smits and Huisman1 already showed that the original GVI was hardly affected by removal of one of the underlying indices. Reduced versions of the index, based on ten instead of eleven indicators had Pearson correlations of over 0.99 with the original index, thus revealing that none of the indicators is essential for its performance.In the same way, we have for the 162 countries for which all indicators are available computed Pearson correlations between our complete index based on ten indicators and the reduced indices based on nine or eight indicators that are used for countries with missing data. These correlations are presented at the bottom line of Table 2. They show that the reduced version with GDPc missing is 0.978 correlated with the complete one, the one with poverty missing 0.997, the one with governance missing 0.993, the one with GDPc and governance missing 0.946 and the one with urbanization and life expectancy missing 0.963. We therefore can conclude that also in our projection data the GVI is not very sensitive to the removal of one or two indicators.This stability of the GVI against removal of (sub)indices might seem surprising at first glance. However, this finding is in line with similar findings for other indices64,74 and with recent evidence that the human aspects of development are highly correlated with each other45,46,77. Socioeconomic vulnerability seems to be a low-dimensional phenomenon, as is also suggested by the finding of Smits and Huisman1 that the original GVI, based on eleven indicators, is highly correlated (0.77 - 0.94) with the vulnerability subcomponents coping capacity, adaptive capacity and sensitivity of more traditional indices like ND-GAIN14, INFORM15 and World Risk Index16, that are based on many more indicators (45, 54, and 27 respectively).Poverty, governance and genderFor poverty, governance and gender, projection data is available in the SSP projections database, but the definitions in that database differ from the definitions required for the construction of the GVI. For these variables therefore more extensive regression prediction models had to be made, which were presented in the Method section. In Fig. 5, graphs are provided of the predicted values against the dependent variables to indicate the quality of these models.Fig. 5Scatterplots for predicted values of regression models and outcome variables poverty, WGI and GDI.Full size imageFor the poverty headcount ratio, we had to translate the older definition used in the SSP database in terms of US$ 3.20 a day in 2011 international dollars PPP into the (equivalent) new World Bank definition in terms of US$ 3.65 a day in 2017 international dollars PPP (Eq. 3 in the Method section). In the upper panel of Fig. 5, the predicted value of this regression model is plotted against the outcome variable Pov365. As in wealthier countries there are very few persons below this poverty line, there is an overrepresentation of observations around zero, but overall no large outliers are observed (which is also in line with the high Adj. R2 of 91.4).This is also the case in the middle panel of Fig. 5, which shows a similar graph for the regression model that translates the projections of the WGI as created by Andrijevic et al.38 into the version used in the GVI Database (Eq. 4 in the Method section). The graph shows a very clear linear relationship between the model’s predicted value and the outcome variable WGI, thus confirming the very high Adj R2 of 94.6.In the bottom panel of Fig. 5, the predicted value of the regression model for GDI is plotted against the outcome variable. Even though the explained variance of this model was with an adj. R2 of 66.4 somewhat lower than that of the poverty and WGI models, it is still substantial and in the plot also a clear linear relationship can be observed.Access to electricity and mobile phonesOur third robustness test focuses on the choices we made in constructing the access to electricity and mobile cellular subscription indicators. While it is likely that for these indicators global saturation will be reached somewhere in the coming decades and that this saturation will be reached earliest under SSP1 and latest under SSP3, the exact years in which this will happen are difficult to predict. We therefore have estimated for each indicator three different scenarios: (1) an intermediate scenario with saturation reached in 2040, 2050 and 2060 respectively; (2) a more optimistic scenario with saturation reached in 2030, 2040 and 2050, and (3) a more pessimistic scenario with saturation reached in 2050, 2060 and 2070.For each of these scenarios we have estimated GVI values and computed Pearson correlations between the values. In all cases the GVI values of the different scenarios were correlated over 0.99 with each other. Also alternative versions of the GVI with the electricity or the cellular subscription indicator completely removed turned out to be over 0.99 correlated with the original index. These results make clear that our projection data are not very sensitive to the definition of these indices. We therefore have chosen to use the intermediate scenario, in which saturation is reached in 2040 under SSP1, in 2050 under SSP2 and in 2060 under SSP3.Using GVI for long-term projectionsA key feature of our approach is the consistent application of the PCA formula developed by Smits & Huisman1. The comparability of the GVI across regions and over time depends on using this same formula throughout. This raises the question whether a formula derived from 2015–2020 data can still be used for projecting vulnerability up to the year 2100?This concern would be justified if the values of the underlying indicators would evolve far beyond the range observed in 2020. However, our data do not support such a development. Instead, we observe a clear trend of convergence: countries with higher levels of vulnerability in 2020 tend to move toward the levels of countries that were less vulnerable at that time. This development is illustrated in Fig. 2, where countries that were most privileged in 2020 show much smaller gains over time compared to those that lagged behind in that year. It is also reflected in a decrease of the standard deviation of the GVI from 382 in 2020 to values in 2100 of 5.6 under SSP1, of 7.2 under SSP2 and of 9.9 under SSP3. Hence, while the speed of convergence varies by scenario, the overall trend is a reduction in variation—not an increase.PCA versus factor analysisA final way to test the robustness of our findings is to compare our PCA results with the outcomes of Factor Analysis (FA) as an alternative method for data reduction and index construction. We therefore have constructed an alternative version of the GVI Projections Database for the 162 countries for which all indicators are available, by using FA instead of PCA. To compare the outcomes of both types of analysis, Pearson correlations were computed between the PCA-based and FA-based indices. These correlations turned out to be larger than 0.98 for all three scenarios, thus highlighting that both methods lead to almost exactly the same index.

Code availability
              
              All indicators used for constructing projected GVI values are freely available from the data collecting organizations. The websites of these organizations are mentioned in the Method section. The GVI Projections Database was constructed from these datasets using SPSS-27. The SPSS file with the syntax code used for creating the projected GVI values from the indicators is included in the GVI Projections Database ZIP Archive available from the Figshare repository at https://doi.org/10.6084/m9.figshare.2835093576 and from the Global Data Lab (www.globaldatalab.org).

items.title: States now have a legal duty to prevent climate harm — justice is in reach
items.body:
WORLD VIEW
                01 September 2025

States now have a legal duty to prevent climate harm — justice is in reach

A July ruling from the International Court of Justice is clear: nations can face consequences if they don’t act on the climate crisis.
                
            
        
        
            
                By

Maina Vakafua Talia0

Maina Vakafua Talia
                
                
                    
                        
                            Maina Vakafua Talia is Tuvalu’s minister of home affairs, climate change and environment.
                        
                    
                
                
                    
                        
                            View author publications
                            
                                
                                    Search author on:
                                    PubMed
                                     Google Scholar

Twitter
            
        
    
    
        
            Facebook
            
        
    
    
        
            Email

The salt spray of the Pacific Ocean is in my blood; I grew up watching the tides shape the shores of the islands of Tuvalu. But now, those tides are rising relentlessly, eroding lands, swallowing homes, decimating livelihoods and washing away the futures of communities. Entire islands are sinking. One-third of Tuvalu’s citizens are seeking ‘climate refuge’ in Australia.Climate change is not a distant threat; it is our daily reality.But there is hope. At the end of July, in The Hague, the Netherlands, I bore witness to a historic moment. The International Court of Justice (ICJ) delivered the advisory opinion that states have a legal duty to prevent climate harm and, importantly, that they can be held accountable for the consequences of their actions, through financial compensation or other forms of restitution.A message from island leaders: protect the Pacific Ocean from deep-sea miningThe ruling means that climate justice is no longer simply a moral obligation, but a matter of international law. This feels like a seismic shift. The relentless cries from front-line communities across the Pacific, who have long borne the brunt of a crisis we did not create, have been heard.The ICJ offered clarity on fossil fuels in particular: producing, licensing and subsidizing them could constitute an “internationally wrongful act” for which states can be held liable under international law. Nations have a duty to reduce greenhouse-gas emissions — and the court highlighted the legal liability that could arise from expanding fossil-fuel infrastructure in the face of clear scientific warnings.It is especially powerful that this legal breakthrough stems from the efforts of small island nations, launched by courageous Pacific youth in 2019, initially in Vanuatu then through cross-border collaborations. It is a reminder that those most affected by the climate crisis are also among the most determined in addressing it. Through efforts ranging from grassroots movements to international diplomacy, Pacific island nations have charted a path that places justice at the centre of climate governance. This is a powerful example of vulnerable voices driving transformative change at the highest levels of international law.Why we should protect the high seas from all extraction, foreverThe ICJ also emphasized that cooperation between states is central to meaningful climate action, and identified treaties as a crucial tool for coordinated implementation. This gives wind to the sails of emerging legal instruments. A fossil-fuel non-proliferation treaty has been proposed, for example, that would provide legal grounding for states to pursue coordinated, binding action on a fossil-fuel phase-out and a just transition to renewable energy. It is currently supported by 17 nations, including Tuvalu, that are shaping the treaty proposal and discussing how to involve others and initiate a formal negotiation process. A high-level ministerial meeting in Belém, Brazil, in November, has been planned alongside the COP30 climate talks to move the process forward.
